notes: Entry-level Buick Series 40 through Great Depression era (1930-1935). Inline-8 engine. Multiple body styles. RWD. Mechanical brakes, 6-volt electrical system. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects early 1930s brass-era proximity, Depression-era production variations, mechanical brake systems, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Series 40 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First and second generation Century (1936-1958, wartime gap 1943-1945). Performance model with Roadmaster engine in lighter Special body. Name signified 100 mph capability. Buick straight-8 engines. Multiple body styles. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1930s-1950s vintage complexity, WWII production gap, and transition-era mechanical systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Century article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation flagship Roadmaster (1936-1953, wartime production gap). Buick straight-8 engine. Luxury full-size sedan. Multiple upscale body styles. RWD body-on-frame. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1930s-1950s vintage complexity, WWII era production variations, and obsolete systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Roadmaster article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Top-of-line luxury series (1936-1942). Buick straight-8 engine. Ultra-luxury appointments, long wheelbase. RWD. Sedan and limousine body styles. Discontinued due to WWII, not revived postwar. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects 1930s-1940s vintage luxury complexity, ultra-rare limited production, and specialized restoration requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Limited article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Series 50 Super mid-range model (1939-1941, later continued as just 'Super' postwar). Buick inline-8 engine. Multiple body styles. RWD. Positioned between Special and Roadmaster. Production halted 1942 for WWII. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects late-1930s/early-1940s vintage complexity and pre-war construction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Super article, December 19, 2024 revision.
